awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Hybrid Experimental-Numerical Methodology and Field Calibration for Characterization of Peak Wind Effects on Low-Rise Buildings and Their Appurtenances
awd_abstract_narration:
Mitigating hurricane damage to building envelopes and appurtenances, particularly for low-rise buildings, remains a principal challenge to achieving coastal resilience.  Building envelopes include roof and wall cladding systems and openings such as windows, doors, and garage doors. Building appurtenances include roof-mounted renewable energy devices such as photovoltaic arrays, rooftop equipment, telecommunications equipment, and architectural ornamentation such as spires and trellises.  During hurricanes, damage to cladding elements and appurtenances can puncture the building envelope and render the building unusable due to water intrusion and loss of interior contents. Such damage largely results from underestimation of peak wind loads on these components.  This research will synthesize field data, experiments, and numerical analysis to more accurately characterize peak wind loads and wind-induced vibrations on low-rise buildings. Better characterization of peak wind loads can lead to better design and retrofit of cladding and appurtenances, thus reducing building vulnerabilities and community losses during major windstorm events. This research will foster sustainable, high-performance buildings with wind-resilient and renewable on-site energy generation systems, to reduce societal disruption from windstorm-induced power outages. The project will enhance the education of underrepresented student groups by leveraging STEM programs and using research outcomes to inform the next generation professionals on windstorm damage mechanisms of low-rise building roofs and how to improve on-site renewable energy systems. Finally, telepresence will be used during testing to increase awareness of wind hazard impacts and serve as a multiplier to reach additional audiences.  Data from this project will be made available in the NSF-supported Natural Hazards Engineering Research Infrastructure (NHERI) Data Depot (https://www.DesignSafe-ci.org). 

Major gaps in fundamental knowledge exist in the estimation and mitigation of peak wind effects on low-rise buildings and their non-structural components, which are vulnerable to damage under high winds. First, for low-rise buildings, large-scale models are needed for accurate testing. However, these scales impose constraints on turbulence simulation, resulting in unconservative wind tunnel estimates of peak aerodynamic loads in areas of strong vorticity where damage is typically initiated.  Second, for building appurtenances (e.g., rooftop solar panels), wind-induced resonant vibrations at high frequencies are unaccounted for in current wind load provisions. The research objective is to create a new physics-based, hybrid experimental-numerical methodology for accurately predicting peak wind effects on low-rise building cladding and appurtenances that (a) uses large-scale, high Reynolds number physical model tests that accurately simulate high frequency turbulence, (b) augments the test results with post-test numerical analysis to incorporate the effects of missing low frequency turbulence and dynamic responses, and (c) accounts for interference effects from surrounding structures. This methodology will be developed through a synthesis of in-situ data on building components with results from large-scale experiments at the NSF-supported NHERI Wall of Wind experimental facility at Florida International University and associated numerical analysis. This new methodology, supported by field calibration, will allow obtaining peak wind load estimates that: (a) are not subject to errors due to scaling effects, (b) include the effects of various scales of turbulence in the oncoming flow, including low frequency gusts and smaller eddies generated by the surrounding structures and by the building itself, and (c) incorporate the resonant amplification of vibrations of smaller appurtenances induced by high frequency turbulent eddies.  This research will also contribute to formulating procedures that will enhance the ability of conventional boundary layer wind tunnels to simulate turbulence for larger model scales than are currently possible, and achieving new design guidelines for wind-induced dynamic effects on building components, needed in view of observed widespread hurricane-induced damage to such components. In addition, this research will lay the foundation for the formulation of structural and functional fragility curves with and without retrofitting strategies that can incentivize citizens to adopt cost-effective retrofits. Field data on peak wind effects, made available in the NHERI Data Depot, will inform the research and professional communities and help benchmark future computational fluid dynamics tools to enhance design and achieve more resilient communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Building appurtenances, such as rooftop photovoltaic (PV) systems, are vulnerable to damage during extreme wind events such as hurricanes. To have more robust designs of PV systems, improved estimation of the peak wind effects is deemed necessary. The major goal of this project was to create a new physics-based methodology for accurately predicting peak wind loads on low-rise buildings and their appurtenances, such as rooftop PV systems. This is expected to lay the foundation for enhancing community resilience by reducing future windstorm-induced damages to the low-rise building envelope and appurtenances and to building functionalities. To achieve this major goal, in-situ and Wall of Wind full- and large-scale experiments, as well as numerical analysis, were performed to examine deficiencies in current physical modeling and building codes. The new hybrid physical-numerical method is expected to enhance wind loading analysis, improve standards for loading formulation, and improve future prediction of damage to buildings and their appurtenances.

Field measurements on PV arrays and roof cladding on a real-world building helped to calibrate and validate the peak estimation methodology. The in-situ measurements were complemented by full- and large-scale wind tunnel testing at the 12-fan Wall of Wind (WOW) at Florida International University (FIU) to validate the hybrid experimental-numerical methodology. This project boosted the capabilities of the 12-fan WOW at FIU to model the dynamic effects of wind-induced vibrations on building appurtenances. The WOW, the largest and most powerful university research facility of its kind and capable of simulating up to Category 5 hurricane, is bridging the gap between field measurements of wind effects on structures and conventional small-scale testing for low-rise buildings. The WOW is one of the shared-use national Experimental Facilities (EFs) supported by the National Science Foundation (NSF) under the Natural Hazards Engineering Research Infrastructure (NHERI) program. The NHERI WOW EF is providing a unique physical infrastructure for testing hurricane resilient products and technologies. Several academic researchers from various institutions and industry participants are using this facility for research and testing purposes.

The expected contributions of this research project include new knowledge on wind effects on roof cladding and rooftop PV systems which will help to achieve low-rise buildings and appurtenances designed or retrofitted for far more realistic wind loads than those currently in use, thus reducing community vulnerability. The new knowledge will foster novel technologies to make building appurtenances more resilient to wind impacts.

The research project has the potential to benefit society through future positive economic impacts due to damage reduction. In addition, the activities can contribute to advancing the National Science and Technology Council’s goal of fostering sustainable high-performance buildings with wind-resilient renewable energy systems for reliable on-site energy generation capabilities. This is especially important in terms of reducing societal disruption from power outages during storms. The expected damage reduction and enhanced building functionalities will promote economic prosperity and healthy, adaptive, resilient communities.

The project provided hands-on experience and effective training to Wall of Wind students and engineers. The findings and outcomes of the work have been disseminated through several avenues including peer-reviewed articles. Research results have been presented at multi-disciplinary national and international conferences and workshops. The findings of wind-induced dynamic effects on photovoltaic systems were shared with American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE) wind load committee to investigate the current ASCE 7 Standard’s criterion related to dynamic amplification. The WOW data are being archived on the DesignSafe-CI platform to allow potential reuse by other researchers.


Last Modified: 10/09/2024
Modified by: Arindam Chowdhury
